content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game. It had all the good things a poker night game should have, and it carried not onyl big name characters, but unlockables for 2 other games. But after several hours of gameplay, I have to toss it into the♥♥♥♥♥♥pile.The Banter between the characcters is good, but in general the game is insulting to the player with every move they make. After wiping all of them out 3 times, being called an idiot for the moves I make just starts to♥♥♥♥♥♥me off. Bad move.But seeing as I piad a buck and a quarter for the game, I wasn't going to complain. But it had another, nastier secret.4 times in a row I had a winning full house. 4 times in a row I went all in because I had a winning full house. 4 times I lost because it only counted it as 3 of a kind. The game can't even do the basic poker playing that my 1980's Macintosh could do with ease. They got a few rights, slapped together a few voice actors and put nothing into the game mechanics. Then they insult you on top of it. If you want to throw away your money for nostalgia, this is your game. If you are looking to play poker...let's hope you like long dialog before it gives you a chance to do anything.1 out of 5 stars. And the 1 is because I liked a couple of the characters.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												People sometimes sit there for ten or twenty seconds at a time. And they like to say the same things, over, and over, and over again. Yes Sam, we get it, dogs can see in colour. And yes Brock, you can buy a lot of bowie knives with that money.It's very buggy, and I can't really recommend it even for the promos. Clicking a button too soon locks up the game completely, and everyone just sits there staring at you forever. And if you want the promos, you have to complete three challenges to unlock a bounty challenge. Those three challenges can be something like, "Win a showdown with just a kicker". In other words, I hope you like poker, because you're going to be playing a LOT of it.Basically, it's poker. But if you want poker, there's better things for it. Like going out, getting friends, and playing with them. Only buy this if you want the promo items.

												MORE GLADOS PLEASE!!!You like Poker? You like playing Poker with fictional characters of some of your games? You would like to play poker with the always "motivational" advice of GLADOS of Portal 2?Well, then this is your Poker game!I like the idea of playing one or two hands of poker in a while. And if you are into some funny dialogues as kind of "story" you will experience some good time with Poker Night 2. I played the first part as well but part 2 is even better because of GLADOS is being the card dealer. I think "her" monologues from Protal 2 are some of the funniest things in computer gaming history.As special motivation you can win some items for other computer games (Team Fortress 2 & Borderlands) if you complete some special tasks. And I really would like to see a third part of Poker Night. Maybe with some skins for CS:GO this time. Wouldn't mind to beat a terrorist or counter at the poker table ;)

Posted: July 11, 2014
												the real problem with this game is the impossiblity of the challenges needed in order to get into the prize games.it gives you three "challenges" which are like "steal the blinds". very easy. I did the first 6 in the game i got them.the problem is the achievment: "win a showdown with a better kicker". I've had that challenge for the longest time and lost countless showdowns with a smaller kicker. I would suggest that a skip challenge or complete 3/4 to progress would be better. this challenge is garbage. me complaining about odds: yeah this game is fun if you like losing. It's obviously possible to do well but it requires so much luck. I cant count the number of times I will go in with 70%+ odds and lose out. the dialog is fun for the first hour but then its slow and repetitive.after 17 hours I have 500k. one win = 100k and 5 losses = -100kthat means I'm five wins over average, which means about a 4:1 lose:win ratiothose odds are complete depressing garbage. with no rhyme or reason i constantly lose on decent odds

												I enjoyed this game, honestly. The dialogue is great and the challenge is at a rough but attainable level. I felt like I was playing Hold 'Em poker with old friends. What I'm most disapointed about is the lack of support with the Borderlands 2 skins. I've unlocked everything but as many times and I mash download, check my linked SHiFT account, and even checked my NewU station in Borderlands 2.Now as disapointed as I am with spending 12 hours to get these rewards and come up with nothing I can still recommend its a great game... just don't purchase this game for the BL2 skins... you will be massively disapointed. 7/10Edit 1/4/14: After working with the wonderful folks at gearbox support they have corrected the issue and I now have my skins!

content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												With $96,000 in a 1 on 1 against ash, he gets 2 aces the flop then revealing another ace or even 2, 3 hands in a row, then getting a 1% chance flush, a 20% chance straight, and continues his hands that cannot ever lose until I have 20k and he has 80k; this♥♥♥♥♥♥didn't happen once, I had this or other such systematic forced losses over and over again. So if you want to play poker I suggest you find a game where the odds and the players involved matter and it isn't a pre-determined flop and hand before you even get your cards.Not only that but any time I had any chance of winning (that fit to the pre-determined flop) every character just folds, I could simply call and the next chance they get they fold. One might say the point of the game is the witty commentary, but that is only 90 minutes or so, and you can simply listen to that anywhere, when the game is so rigged that you could just go all in every hand and have the same end result why even bother playing? In conclusion, if you want a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game where the only victory you get is a forced fold on a pre-determined hand/flop for all AI and yourself, and spend 30-100 minutes every game only to find out you had no real chance of winning to begin with then you can get this game, but I think you could find a better use for $5, like a cheap aids infected ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with no condoms, at least then when you have a guaranteed end you get to have sex.♥♥♥♥ this game, the items aren't worth it.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												I know almost everyone plays this game for the TF2 items, but here's how that's gonna go.Before we start, an exploit: If you close the game, it resets the last hand dealt when you come back in. Ergo, go all in all you want, there's no riskYou'll steamroll the first game.The second game will have three arbitrary challenges that will happen in any game.The third game will have run out of lines, and all you'll be hearing from this point on is:Well that was a clever move that won't come back to bite you in your ample posterior. Well that was a clever move that won't come back to bite you in your ample posterior. Well that was a clever move that won't come back to bite you in your ample posterior. Well that was a clever move that won't come back to bite you in your ample posterior. Well that was a clever move that won't come back to bite you in your ample posterior. Well that was a clever move that won't come back to bite you in your ample posterior. The poker algorithm is very basic, don't expect any of the other players to react to the possibility of having a hand, they only react to the amount of chips you use to bluff or raise at random to bluff, regardless of the cards on the table. Max will never ever bluff though.Also, you can buy them drinks at the start of the game, which makes them do their very obvious animation that reveals if they have a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ hand.Oh, and they go all-in all the time. They'll go all in for a pair of twos when there's Ace, King, Queen, Jack on the table. In fact, Claptrap loves to go all in on the blinds.Also, after the second game, you will rarely ever win a hand. The characters will always magically have a better hand than you. Oh, you have a Straight Flush? Well, the guy you went all in to has a Royal Flush. However, Brock and Ash always have ♥♥♥♥♥♥ hands. It's always a pair or two, never higher. You'll knock one or both of them on the first hand almost 1/3 times. Visually, it's pretty great. Everyone actually looks very much like they should. AND, unlike the first game, it doesn't have that stilted Telltale Pose-To-Pose animation where the character's face moves into an expression, then their body starts moving, then they stop moving, change faces, start another animation sequence.The characters will talk♥♥♥♥♥♥on every move you make, stopping the flow of the game, which makes you wish they get into a scripted sequence, because when that happens, they just play the ♥♥♥♥ing game.I give this game a Shut The ♥♥♥♥ Up GlaDOS/10

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Don't bother getting this if you played Poker Night 1. The game is the same, and the AI is just as dumb. The only one winning here is whoever decided that rushing out the same game with a slightly different setting and lesser-known characters wasn't a one-way ticket to Hell for excessive greed.Who are these characters anyway? Last game, they got Max from Sam and Max who we should all remember from childhood cartoons, Strong Bad from the most awesome flash website ever created, The Heavy from a FPS, and one original character who was a spoof of what TTG thinks of gamers which was actually somewhat amusing at times.This time, there's a bland angry guy who has the voice of Joe from Family Guy, some annoying robot thing that claims to be from Pandora but definitely was not in Avatar and was probably only included so the graphics people could work less, some guy called Ash who can't be the adult version of the Pokemon character unless he's fighting undead Marowaks or something, and finally the only character who isn't out of nowhere or just made up, Sam from Sam and Max.Even having Sam is barely enough, he was only given about 4 good lines, all where he's talking with Max rather than these other personality-deprived nobodies. Much more often, you're stuck hearing annoying robot guy's excessively long voice clips that can't be skipped and which pause the action (there really should be an option to mute him or replace him with Max or something), or having to hear 10+ times a game everyone overact to every All-In, despite how commonly the AI does it themselves. But at least GLADOS is the dealer so we don't have to hear bland short sailor guy talk much anymore.If you want to play poker online, find some other free website to play it at, it's not worth it to get this just for Sam, Max, and a couple of other much less interesting personalities, all backed by the same stupidly bluffing AI as the last game.

												MORE GLADOS PLEASE!!!You like Poker? You like playing Poker with fictional characters of some of your games? You would like to play poker with the always "motivational" advice of GLADOS of Portal 2?Well, then this is your Poker game!I like the idea of playing one or two hands of poker in a while. And if you are into some funny dialogues as kind of "story" you will experience some good time with Poker Night 2. I played the first part as well but part 2 is even better because of GLADOS is being the card dealer. I think "her" monologues from Protal 2 are some of the funniest things in computer gaming history.As special motivation you can win some items for other computer games (Team Fortress 2 & Borderlands) if you complete some special tasks. 												I picked up this game for a solid key, and i must say it was worth it entirely! This game is extremly fun to play, and knocking players from your favourite games (such as clap trap and Sam) of the table is very enjoyable! However, there is a minor set back that may swing if you want to buy this game or not, and that is the in game items that you can obtain from this game (for tf2 and borderlans). In Poker Night 1, it was random and the players would put their items up, however, now you have to complete a set of challenges, then knock every player of the table in order to win the item. I find this fun and challenging, but i can see why people wouldn't like this change.(Would reccomend picking Poker Night 1 up as well!)

content:
Posted: May 19, 2013
												This game is the bestest! I get to spend so much quality time with my favorite characters from my most favoritest TV show, video games, movie, and comic! The stakes are higher than the predecessor with longer lines, longer banter between characters, a hand-ful of non-playing characters participating in the longer banter, long animation cycles for each action done by all these characters, and the cherry to top it all off: it's all unskippable! Wow! Amazing! I love Claptrap! He's so zany even though he repeats the same dialogue over and over with the same exact tells and resulting actions in the same poker sesh, even repeating himself consecutively! And all of the other characters do this too! I love your repeated naggings, GLaDOS. Please marry me! I read Girls for M and I have some good ideas on how to further highlight how pathetic I am for playing this game, which each and every character in this game rush out to make obvious, and make this all kinkier than it already is, like the repeated flirtations between Claptrap and GLaDOS. Tie me up into a hog-tie like a pig ready for slaughter, stomp on my nards, and take all my money from my wallet, because I'm going to plop down for a preorder of the sequel to this bad boy of a game!

												I'm terrible at poker, but that dosen't stop me from enjoying this game. I'll admit that I bought it for the unlockables and was slightly interested by the characters, but having played it I must say its selling point is the dialogue. It is very well done, with all of the conversations having little to do with what is going on in the hand but more about the games of the characters themselves.  I may have slight bias due to GLaDOS being the dealer (She would not be as funny playing poker, that's for sure) but I would recommend this game to anyone who knows any of the characters here, regardless of how much they like poker. (There is an easy way to win each hand if you suck like I do, just look in the community guides.)

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												As much as I want to recommend this game. I can not. Despite the GlaDoS quotes defintely living up to there potential as in Portal 2, there are extremely minimal of them and they become old very fast. Certain quotes just aren't witty or funny enough and drag out an extra 5 minutes pointlessly. Gameplay lacks as the AI can not calculate simple functions as Identifying a Full House vs a 3 of a kind and may often mistake Full Houses for 3 of a kinds thus making you lose. Also, some hands that you and your opponents get far too good cards to be a coincidence. The chances of you losing can go from an almost certain circumstance to an instant win too often.The aspect of bounties is a pain. Certain bounties are almost unbeatable and render the Item for Team Fortress or Borderlands an extreme waste of time. Such as the Win with a High card as there AI is built to immeditely fold when they do not get anything beyond a pair. The only time this is doable is when you either 1) Get extremely lucky or 2) You get a glitch happen. Either of which will take hours to wait forReview: Despite Quotes being well done, they are minimal and get old. Mechanics for the game require improvement as they are glitchy ocasionally in situations. Bounties will take forever and will not happen fastGameplay:6/10 (Only 2 modes. Could use more)Mechanics:3/10 (The Full house problem just happended again. Seriously) Quotes: 6/10 (GlaDoS quotes are amazing but burn out fast)Replayability: 8/10 (Game is unpredictable) Overal: 5/10

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												AYOOO. I seriously am so glad I bought this game. Easily one of the most unique, and amusing, poker games I've ever played. With a plethora of interesting characters like GLaDOS, Brock Samson, Reginald Van Winslow and Ash Williams, this game has a ton of hysterical moments with each character exchanging quips and discussing various topics like personal servitude and job openings. The gameplay itself is fun and always engaging, using features like 'tells' and 'bounties' to create another layer of challenge and play style is beyond awesome. The different felts, decks and chips give you more reason to keep playing and earning fat stacks and the various easter eggs, references and jokes are all pretty clever. This game is also pretty hard to rage about, even when you lose a hand, just because of how utterly likeable and hilarious the characters are. I recommend this game to any poker fan, especially those who also love Evil Dead, the Venture Bros, Portal, Borderlands. By game mechanics alone, this game is great but when one takes into account the creativy and humor behind it, it's amazing. 10/10.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												I bought this game on a whim but I am definitely glad I did.Telltale Games once again deliver a game full of charm and character and there is little to complain about especially considering the price.This game is in basic a pretty good poker game, it entertains with appealing, crisp visuals and the UI makes play quick and easy. But if you don't especially like poker I wouldn't write this game off. You are joined at the table by Brock Samson from The Venture Bros, CL4P TRP from Borderlands, Ash Williams from Army of Darkness and Sam from Sam and Max. These four characters are packed full of witty and charming dialogue, their conversation and insults keep you very involved in the game and could even entertain you on their own. Each character also has distinct play-styles and always keep you on your toes. Unfortunately the dialogue has the habit of looping which can get extremely dull, most of the jokes stop being funny after about the third time. You might think this game would get fairly boring and inevitably it eventually will but it keeps play interesting with randomised challenges, customizable chips, cards and tables and unlockables for other games. This helps maintain the incentive to win despite being pitted against bots.  Overall it is definitely worth the price, full of charm and life and entertaining on multiple levels but please remember it is a poker game and it's not for everyone.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Did I have fun? YesCould the games be improved? DefinitlyFun, but not enough gameplay past the cards. Should have more upgrades, characters, costumes, higher stakes, ect.The upgrades & room theme mechanic is something good, but i'm still left wanting more.The money holds no weight whatsoever (excluding the 1mil acheivment), which could have been easily fixed with upgrades from the bankroll as apposed to prize tokens that will never be at risk. The prize tokens give absolutely no weight to the upgrading system.Bankroll management is possibly the most important mechanic of poker & it really is shoved in a corner, which is dissapointing.They took away the option to minimize table talk. -_-The A.I. consistently makes nonsence plays. For example, it is not uncommon for Brock to call down three streets of value while holding nothing more than high card 8.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												Telltale returns with their third poker game. This time it has Brock from Venture Bros, Claptrap from Borderlands, Evil Dead's Ash Williams, Telltale's own Sam and Max (originally of Lucas Arts fame), and finally GladOS from Portal as the dealer.The Bruce Campbell impersonator of Ash feels a little underwhelming, and I wish they could have just got Bruce himself in for the role, but all the other characters are spot on. The dialogue is charming. The gaming and betting AI is much improved from the predecessor, and the Animation is much smoother. I also like how the different styles of animation are maintained in the same engine. When you see the different kinds of cell shading on Brock and Claptrap, while having a different style of 3D renduring on Ash, GladOS, and Sam and Max while all staying true to the original styles the characters came from, it is pretty amazing.The only gripe I have is it seems the bluff vs tell animations are at random now, and there really is no longer a way to try and get a read on the characters, even after you buy them alcohol. In that way alone it feels like that is a bit of a downgrade from the previous Poker Night. Every other front seems to have improved though. They have now included Omaha as well as Texas Hold'em.  There is  now more diversified gaming AIs between the characters. For instance, Brock and Ash will constantly get into bidding wars, that everyone else should steer clear of. Finally, unlocking different table, card, and chip sets, also change the decor of the room, as well as add new themed dialoge to the characters and new elimination scenarios, which gives the game a little more longevity and adds to the fun.The cross-game unlockables are kinda meh-ish, but hopefully with so much other stuff in both Team Fortress and Borderlands, that's not the reason you're playing. I still recommend getting this game on it's own merits, and hope that Telltale revisits this franchise in the future, and maybe next time with a rotating cast of more characters.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												You get to play cards with some of the best, iconic characters in video games, comics, television, and movies... and also you get to play with Claptrap.In all seriousness though, this is a great game for people who felt Poker Night 1 was too easy.  Your opponents are more aggressive and smarter, and are more likely to recognize when they have a good hand, or when they know you can't afford to call their bluff.  The game may seem like it cheats, but in all honesty, that's how odds work in poker.  There are times I shouldn't have won but did.  The game requires brains AND guts, and if you have only one or the other, you may find yourself furstrated.  But don't let that discourage you - it's a great way to get your brain working and to build up your guts a bit, so I whole-heartedly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												The first Poker Night was a middle-of-the-road for me, but on the bright side it has taught me a lot of the basics of poker. Poker Night 2, however, seems to take that logic and throw it out the window.Before, your experience mainly depended on your skills with the element of chance that all card games have to offer. However, in Poker Night 2, the odds seem to be stacked against you. (Or at least is a buggy mess, but considering the types of glitches I've come across it's likely the former.)As I mentioned above, this seems to be a buggy mess. For instance, during a showdown against Claptrap, the odds meter on the top of the screen read my odds as 51%.... and Claptrap's as 52%.I've also been the victim of "lesser readings" as I call them, where the game interperets your hand not as the highest it possibly can, but rather as the lowest. For instance, in a 1 on 1 showdown with Max, a Flush that I had was read as a single pair of 2s; still technically right, but ♥♥♥♥♥♥ nonetheless.All in all, Poker Night 2 is a terribly broken trainwreck that pales in comparison to the original. Sure the new opponents are a nice change but I feel that the glitches and bugs it presents make it unworthy of most Steam libraries.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												Total garbage as a poker game.The AI is completely absurd and plays like a dumb, drunk novice. It's essentially like playing against a random number generator. Whether the AI calls, bets, raises, bluffs or folds seems to have absolutely nothing to do with its hand or how the other players are playing the hand. It's as if the game was programmed by someone who has never played poker in their life.On top of that, the user interface is terrible and clunky. There's no option to skip dialogue. Although several of the exchanges between the characters are honestly funny the first or second time you hear them, they quickly lose their luster. Especially after you listen to Claptrap or GladOS smack talking you with the same line for the hundredth time after making a completely reasonable and statistically valid call or raise that just turned into bad luck because of a gut shot turn or river card in a hand that the AI had no business being in after the flop. Seriously, the option to skip dialogue would have gone a long way with this game.This game really has no value other than providing a cheap way to acquire some Borderlands 2 and TF2 vanity items. If you absolutely must have the items, then it's a decent buy.... iiiiiif you're willing to invest hours and hours to get the bounties for the item unlocks.If you're looking for a good poker simulator, stay the hell away from this pile.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2013
												First off all, this game is a major improvement from the first. The characters are way more interesting, you can buy drinks to accentuate your enemie's "tells" and when you buy a full set of cards, chips and table, the Inventory changes style to said set's world. The conversation between the character's is really great, and with the addition of GLaDOS as a dealer, gives you 1 more person that talks. I like the % that each player has in a showdown, giving you an idea of who's winning. To buy additionals, you need tokens, which you always get if you aren't the first to get eliminated. To get the special items for other games, you don't just need to eliminate the person who put it on play, you need to complete 3 challenges then win the tournament. An amazing poker simulator with something to lighten the mood.8/10

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Where do I start?First of all, this is a really bad poker game: dealing hands is clearly not pure chance even though that's how it should be. The computer clearly helps the AI by giving good cards to it in the river most of the time (I tested it just for the heck of it by going for the showdown all the time an at around 80% of the hands the AI won with bad cards by getting help in the river). Because of this Texas Hold'em is basically unplayable as it becomes a luck based guessing game with no strategy involved. Omaha is better so if you really want to see Sam & Max talking trash that game mode is the way to go. The AI itself is pretty bad, it makes stupid decisions while every character has a distinct playstyle that is easy to read. They never change their playstyles, they are always reacting the same way which makes the experience boring.And then there are the so called bounty challenges where completing 3 of them will unlock the chance to compete for one of the character bounties. Some of these challenges are nice and they require a bit of skill to pull off, others are purely luck based with a small percentage being outrageously luck based. This last category absolutely destroys the enjoyment of the game because if you get challenges like "win a hand with 2 opponents going all in "or "win with the higher kicker" your next move will be to just go and uninstall this mess instead of waiting for circumstances you have no chance of affecting occur. What's even worse is that you can't skip these challenges so if you get a bad 3 you're basically done for.Anyway the atmosphere is pretty cool, the unlockable decorations are nice and the characters are funny but everything gets old quickly. There's also no way to skip repeating jokes so you'll hear the same stuff all the time.Bad, really bad game.

Youre there because you want to play some poker. Now going in its way harder than the first game. Ai will know when youre bluffing or when you get them drunk they will use bad cards in your favour. The gameplay stays the same from the first one. Also the jokes are funny as hell but they do repeat themselfs.  Also they added a new mode which is omaha which is a nice edition but now about the loot. Not only do you get in game loot which looks amazing such as Poker felts, cards and chips but also you get Borderlands 2 skins and also Team fortress 2 items.Overall you have an awesome game which is fun as hell and worth it so go ahead and check it and if youre tight on buget pick this one instead of the first but if you have enought money for both thats awesome so go ahead and check it out i give it a 8.5/10

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												No multiplayer is a huge downside for any card game involving multiple "players". But the witty banter between the iconic characters is enjoyable, I found myself not cutting to the next hand if I was out just so I could enjoy the back and forth. It's also interesting how the graphics for each character remain true to the games they are from, though I did have random frame issues (I run a 7970 and a 4GHz 8 core processor) at times for no apparent reason. Overall, I bought the game for $2.50 cents during the holiday sale and I'm not at all disappointed. Though, any higher I'm afraid I wouldn't be willing to pay simply due to the lack of multiplayer, but anyone that enjoys poker and is a fan of the characters in this game, not minding the lack of multiplayer should have no issue picking this game up.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												Damn you Telltale.  How about making a game that works for a change.  Everybody is having startup issues with all of your games, because you make them all the exact same way and haven't found a way to fix the issue.  I tried every trick to get this game to startup.  The kicker was that once I found a way that got it working, after I closed it and started it up again it wouldn't work.  Each solution would work maybe twice, and then its back to the same old crashing before the telltale logo even comes up.  I was able to get it to start in compatibility with windows 98/ME but then it must store the save file somewhere else when you do that because it made makes you start over.  I started looking to see if I could find where the new save file is placed, but I realized that this game is taking up waaay more of my time than its worth.  I have literally spent 45 minutes starting it up and having it crash on me.  So I no longer expect Telltale games to work, because I have had the same problems with Poker Night 1 and the Walking Dead.  I paid for your games Telltale and you have repeatedly screwed me over.  I have friends who have the exact same problems, and the forums are filled with complaints about them not working but I have seen no remedy on Telltales side.  Don't buy their games.EDIT: After I building a new computer, I figured I'd redownload this game and give it a try.  It works now, but I am refraining from messing with the graphics settings because I'm pretty sure that is what caused the game to malfunction on my other computer.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												It's hard for me to properly express how dissapointed I am with Poker Night at the Inventory 2 when comparing it to its predecessor. However, it's not hard for me to point out all of its extremely blatent flaws so I'll cut to the chase.If you like playing Texas Hold em' or Omaha style poker for fun, move on. If you like playing Texas Hold em' or Omaha style poker at a simulated friendly table, move on. Now, if you like playing Texas Hold em' or Omaha style poker at an unfriendly table AND having the computer always stack the deck in favor of the other players, then this is the poker game for you.You are forced to play ridiculously conservatively if you want so much as a chance at winning. Have a pair of kings? The computer gets a pair of aces. You have two pair? The computer gets three of a kind. Bluffing might as well not even exist since even if the computer bluffs with a worse hand than yours, they'll still draw what they need to beat you 80% of the time.On top of feeling more akin to playing a slot machine with two of its reels broken than playing a fair game of poker, this game's dialoge gets grating fast. Most of the longer conversations in the first Poker Night at the Inventory were still about only two thirds as long as some of the drawn out gags in this game. This wouldn't be as bothersome as it is if you could decrease how often characters talk like in the first game, but for seemingly no reason, this and the difficulty option have been removed.In conclusion, if you want to buy a fun single player poker game that feels fair with entertaining characters, buy Poker Night at the Inventory and skip this sadly inferior sequel.

There are bounties as well that can be unlocked to use in other telltale games so that is a perk as well which keeps you playing. Have fun and lighten up with some "Poker Night 2".

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 14, 2013
												Prior to this game, I was under the impression that a series was supposed to get better as it went on. Apparently Telltale is losing their touch...Poker Night was a tough act to follow, and while this game had the potential to top it with its cast of characters, it fails hard on many levels, not the least of which is the CPU's blatant cheating (why on earth would they make a cheating AI when they had a perfectly-working non-cheating one in the first game? Cheating AIs are only supposed to be employed when there is no better alternative ... or when your game is Mario Kart). Went all-in after being dealt a pair of aces? Someone else got a pair of jacks, and the next card on the table is 100% going to be a jack. Game tells you you have a 99% chance of winning? Your opponent is guaranteed to get the one card that would let them win. Just folded? Oh look - THERE'S that card you needed! Too bad you'll never see it again.There is also a disproportionately large percentage of the dialog dedicated solely to insulting the player. I know it's supposed to be funny, but when your game isn't exactly relying on its own fun merit to begin with (face it, the only worthwhile takeaway is the TF2 and BL2 loot), calling the player a moron for playing it is the last thing you want to do if you expect them to keep playing.Speaking of dialog, what banter isn't used to call the player an idiot is repetitive and dull. The characters have different conversations based on the unlockable theme currently in use, but there are only maybe 4 or 5 per theme, meaning you'll hear the same crap over and over unless you change tables every tournament. They're not nearly as funny as the first game either. There are some humorous animations when others get busted out (if you aren't the first one to bust out, which you will be 90% of the time - again, cheating CPUs), but they don't always play, so you'll likely never see most of them. (Speaking of animations, characters, especially GLaDOS, get frozen mid-animation A LOT. It's these kinds of bugs that remind you why testing is necessary.)NOT recommended. Save your $5 and find something worthwhile, like Just Cause 2 when it goes on sale again, which it does often.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 29, 2013
												Let's face it: Texas Hold'em is the most manly gambling game right after Russian Roulette. You have to stay focused througout the whole tournament and you have to play it cool even if the River Card is completing your Full House.The problen is: In your every day life you will not get a lot of chances to sit down at a round table in a smoke filled backroom of your local pub and play this awesome game with 4 other soldiers of fortune.So you will most likely restort to online poker. A faceless bunch of nobodies that probably play on 20 Tables at the same time will contantly fold the crap out of you. So you are doomed to collect one blind after another until one of them gets a lucky hand but blows it with the obvious tell of betting after 50 rounds of folding.Long Story short: IT SUCKS!But here comes the solution: POKER NIGHT 2Here you play with an awesome bunch of very indiviual characters that, even though they are played by the AI, are better than most online poker ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. They bluff, they taunt you, they play dirty and when they are drunk they tell once in a while.You love them for the humor and hate them when their Kicker make you lose a fortune. If you liked Poker Night 1 you wil LOVE Poker Night 2.If Poker Night 1 was too easy and repetetive: Give Poker Night 2 a chance! It has WAY more Audio Recordings, the AI is WAY better and you get to do a lot of other stuff while playing Poker. Buy these guys some drinks and make them drunk. Try make them bet their Throphies. Buy new Decks, Felts and Chips.And be honest with me: GladOS as the dealer? ♥♥♥♥ YEAH!

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Poker Night 2 has you facing off against Brock Sampson, Sam (from the Sam & Max games), Claptrap, and Ash Williams (from Army of Darkness) in Texas Hold 'Em and Omaha poker tournaments.  GLADOS acts as the dealer for the tournaments, and all the character banter back and forth.  The character interaction is funny and makes for an enjoyable atmosphere while you play Texas Hold 'Em or Omaha poker.  This has been a surprise hit for me, and the only small criticism I will make is that I would like to see more characters show up in the game to add some variety.  It would be great if they created some DLC that added more characters, or incorporated the characters from the first game.Fun game and totally worth the asking price.  If you can pick it up at half price during the summer sale go for it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												A solid little poker game, highlighted by the great writing and voice-acting of your "celebrity" opponents.The concept is simple enough: stars from the world of geek come out to play poker against each other (and you, of course), and the winner takes all.  The game features both No Limit Texas Hold 'Em and Omaha variations, and that's it.  While the poker engine is pretty solid, it's not likely to convert hardcore players.  The real fun is in the interactions of your opponents, who include Brock Samson from the Venture Brothers cartoon series, Claptrap from the Borderlands franchise, Ash Williams from the Evil Dead series, and Sam of Sam & Max fame.  Max, of course, is on hand to make mischief, and everyone's favorite evil robot Glados deals the cards and provides sarcastic commentary about the players.  Borderlands vixen Moxxi serves as the bartender, but oddly enough, she never says a word.  Weird.The problems with the game are easy to predict: the dialog begins recycling itself after a handful of sessions, and the players never change their tells or strategies, making them fairly easy to defeat after some practice.  These issues are handily countered by the game's price, which is at most five bucks and usually less thanks to Steam sales and flash bargains.  It's unlikely that this game will be something you play hardcore for months on end, but as a low-cost slice of passing entertainment, it's hard to pass this one up.  Granted, if you don't know the characters involved, 75% of the humor might go right over your head.Bonuses include themed decks, felts, and chips for the respective franchises of each character, and bounty items from each player that unlock new skins and items in both Borderlands 2 and Team Fortress 2.If you're a fan of poker and some of the characters involved, this is kind of a no-brainer.  The game won't hold your attention forever, but for the price, it will more than hold up its end for some good laughs and solid card-playing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												After really enjoying Poker Night at the Inventory (Poker Night 1) I thought well do I really need another poker game. Surely that one would do right. Well eventually at a slightly reduced price I jumped at Poker Night 2 and I regret never getting it sooner and at full price. This game is far better. The humour is better. The poker engine itself seems better. Poker Night 2 introduces Omaha poker which I have only really played a couple of times as I find it easier to work with a two card hand than a five but if you have a favourite type of poker you can stick with that and maybe occassionally switch to the other just to mix it up a bit.Even though theres only still a fairly limited but certainly less limited amount of lines the other characters say it is varied enough to keep those same lines interesting, and the characters refer more to you the player which brings you into the immersion more. You can buy players drinks to uncover their bluffs or make them have poor judgements. Although subjective I do prefer the characters playing here than on the first game. Brock Samson was not to familiar with before playing but it did not stop me enjoying his character enough for me to look into the Venture Brothers.It certainly is not going to be a game that you are going to play until hell freezes over but if you want the thrills of poker without the cash loss with a mix of the feeling you are playing a video game not random chance simulator 1995. I would certainly say $5 is well spent here.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												Thoroughly enjoyable! This game is great after a couple of beverages, on a lonely night. Feels like sitting around with a few friends, only these friends are Brock frikkin' Samson and Ash! I have to admit how sad I was not to hear Bruce Campbell's quips, but the voice actor they used did well, none the less.They created a great atmosphere with this one as even though the characters talk and jibe, it's rarely annoying.With so many lines of dialogue, the longevity of this game is extended. I must admit to only expecting a few back and forths, but I feel they really went all out.The poker side of things is fun, trying to suss out your opponents. I found myself, on more than one occasion, trying to read their tells and listen for bluffs... tried and failed (at least they couldn't see MY lousy poker face).There is the sad note however, that there is no multiplayer. Perhaps we'll see it in a future version?Anyways, right price, lots of fun, do yourself a favour and have a crack at it.You're going to giggle, I promise.

Most of what I find is 2D online poker. Who the hell plays cards for real money? It's only in movies or once a lifetime in Vegas. Anyway, I thought you should know this.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												It's a poker game, it's only gameplay mechanic is playing poker. So if you don't like poker then don't play the game, it is as simple as that. The game is quite humorous because of its characters that branch from different game franchises, GLADOS from Portal, Claptrap from Borderlands and others. However the brilliant writing is ruined by the repetitiveness of them, the same jokes are constantly repeated and it got to the point where I just muted the game because I couldn't stand the repeated lines anymore. The unlocks help to customize your experience and help to keep you playing. The game suffers from only having two modes, it would be much better if the game was able to blend in some more modes. 7/10- Poker is fun, characters are fun, jokes are fun but are repeated and the game needs more modes.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												Poker Night 2 is not a game you can put 8 hours a day for months into. Its a fun poker sim which aims to emulate the banter and party atmosphere of a game of poker with friends. It suceeds at this admirably, the writing and voice acting is superb, where else will you find Glados, Claptrap, Ash and Sam and Max in one game mocking your ability to bluff. There are two flavoures of poker on offer, Texas Hold'em and Omaha, the tutorials for both are more than capable for total begginners or if, like me, you're a bit rusty. It won't last you long but if you can pick this up for cheap its a few hours of good entertainment

												Poker Night 2 is an entertaining Hold 'Em game that is more about the characters involved than the poker action. The characters all have their own stories and jokes to tell during the game (although it feels like Ash gets the short end of the stick a bit). Don't play this game expecting any kind of serious poker sim; the AI decisions are strange to say the least. It's a humorous timekiller with enough themes and dialogue from the characters to keep things fresh for several hours.

												Poker Night 2 uses the same concept as the first game, but with a different cast of characters. While I'm fairly sure the amount of dialogue at least matches the first game, it seems to repeat the lines far more often in comparison. Additionally to Texas Hold 'Em you can now play Omaha as well, which I highly recommend, because it is much more fun. The Poker Night 2 unlockables are felts, chips and decks for each of the represented games/movies/TV series and activating a full set completely changes the room you are playing in AND the soundtrack! The game loses a few points due to repetition and an unfair AI (Texas Hold' Em).

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Buy it when it goes on sale and have a few laughs.  The characters, setting, and banter are great.  Just don't expect the actual poker part to be fun.  This game cheats and it cheats HARD.  In real life, your odds of getting heads in a coinflip is 1:2.  In this game, it's more like 1:6.Try it.  Wait for all but one opponent to be eliminated and go all in with a good initial deal.  Mathematically speaking, you should have a 50% chance of having the best hand at the end.  Despite this, the computer ALMOST ALWAYS manages to get one better card than you.

												if you're a fan of the fandom and love some great juxtaposition, along with gambling, you're not just a well rounded person you're probably a fan of poker night! this game brings us the great game of texas hold em (and omaha if you're into the variant of the game) and introduces us to some of the greatest characters anyone has ever fantasized shooting the breeze with. the amount of content (as far as the characters go) is staggering! not only can you also change the theme of the cards and table, but if you play your cards right, you can change the setting of the bar as well and even get the characters to comment on it! This game is great for anyone whose fans of the venture brothers, tall tell games, Portal or Bruce Campbell. there are a couple downsides....its not multiplayer and Mr. Campbell isnt actually facilitating his voice, but they found a great stand in and everyone else are the original voice actors. do yourself a favor and get this pass time game. you wont be disappointed!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 24, 2013
												 I'm no gambler, but even I can tell this is a terrible poker game. The character writing is funny though, and the scene changes when you use all the items in a set are fun.If you have any knowledge of poker, stay the hell away from this game because the nonsensical betting will infuriate you. If you just want the unlocks, you may get them very fast, or you may NEVER get them, depending on which of the challenges you get. I got all the items but Glados' in a couple hours, and I'm currently stuck having to win 3 hands in a row to unlock hers. That's unlikely when the other players raise like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ monkeys.Winning tournaments is easy - fold on any opening less than two face cards (unless you're the big blind and can get a 'free' look at the flop) and let the idiots knock each other out of the game.Winning multiple hands in a row  is just luck though. In the showdown, be prepared to have your blinds stolen a lot, unless you decide to play like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ monkey too.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												I am not a video game poker fan, but I do like the real thing, even though I am not a gambler with it in real life, I simply like the game. That said that is what is done nicely here, the game. The atmosphere being so well done from the first one to this one is also a plus. This is a lighthearted fun little tromp through the game that does not take itself too seriously. I hesitated to review it as like I said I am no e-poker afficiando, so the biggest thing on offer here, the poker AI itself is not something I can compare to other games besides the first one, briefly. Let me say that it is fun to play around with, the ai does seem uneven at times as there are really really long odds for one of the computer opponents to beat your nice flush or straight, and they get it. A Lot. It is still fun and thier banter is funny for the most part. Catching it on sale is the icing on the cake for me, but this one has already been reccomended by me to some others and it is good for some laughs and occaisonally a halfway decent round of poker breaks out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												All the fun of Poker Night 1 but even more to offer.  An all new cast of cult classic characters will have you laughing hard at their discussions and bickering.  The poker is just as good as ever and you can read more in my Poker Night 1 review to see what I mean and this time they even added an Omaha style just to mix it up a bit.  The addition of the odds screen is a fun little aspect and something I wished was in the first one.  Again their are lots of unlockables but with the bonus that if everything is deployed for a single character the entire Inventory changes and they get a new outfit.  Speaking of, more bounty unlockables for extra content in Team Fortress 2 , Borderlands 2, etc.  The dialogue was one of the best and worst things about Poker Night 1 in that the first time you hear something funny about or from a character you especially like it's hillarious.  At least until the 6th time you've heard it.  There are much much more conversations between characters so the repitition is way less but unavoidably there is some.  The only real problem is coincidently the infamous host of this game: GlaDos.  She was the big reason everyone was talking about this game but she's actually the worst part of it because all of her dialogue is criticism of you.  You bet and she scolds you, you fold and she scolds you, you go all-in and she scolds you, you call a bet and she scolds you, you win the game and the scolds you (no, not joking).  And her lines are much fewer and are by far the most annoying and repetitive you will hear.  I've gotten a reflex when I see her come down from the cieling I mute my sound and when she leaves I unmute it and it's way better.Anyway, point is that I enjoy card games like Spades, Solitaire, and Hearts that come with computers and this is that times 100 with Moxxi's cleavage on top of it.  I play it every week.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 14, 2013
												Prior to this game, I was under the impression that a series was supposed to get better as it went on. Apparently Telltale is losing their touch...Poker Night was a tough act to follow, and while this game had the potential to top it with its cast of characters, it fails hard on many levels, not the least of which is the CPU's blatant cheating (why on earth would they make a cheating AI when they had a perfectly-working non-cheating one in the first game? Cheating AIs are only supposed to be employed when there is no better alternative ... or when your game is Mario Kart). Went all-in after being dealt a pair of aces? Someone else got a pair of jacks, and the next card on the table is 100% going to be a jack. Game tells you you have a 99% chance of winning? Your opponent is guaranteed to get the one card that would let them win. Just folded? Oh look - THERE'S that card you needed! Too bad you'll never see it again.There is also a disproportionately large percentage of the dialog dedicated solely to insulting the player. I know it's supposed to be funny, but when your game isn't exactly relying on its own fun merit to begin with (face it, the only worthwhile takeaway is the TF2 and BL2 loot), calling the player a moron for playing it is the last thing you want to do if you expect them to keep playing.Speaking of dialog, what banter isn't used to call the player an idiot is repetitive and dull. The characters have different conversations based on the unlockable theme currently in use, but there are only maybe 4 or 5 per theme, meaning you'll hear the same crap over and over unless you change tables every tournament. They're not nearly as funny as the first game either. There are some humorous animations when others get busted out (if you aren't the first one to bust out, which you will be 90% of the time - again, cheating CPUs), but they don't always play, so you'll likely never see most of them. (Speaking of animations, characters, especially GLaDOS, get frozen mid-animation A LOT. It's these kinds of bugs that remind you why testing is necessary.)NOT recommended. Save your $5 and find something worthwhile, like Just Cause 2 when it goes on sale again, which it does often.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2013
												Let's face it: Texas Hold'em is the most manly gambling game right after Russian Roulette. You have to stay focused througout the whole tournament and you have to play it cool even if the River Card is completing your Full House.The problen is: In your every day life you will not get a lot of chances to sit down at a round table in a smoke filled backroom of your local pub and play this awesome game with 4 other soldiers of fortune.So you will most likely restort to online poker. A faceless bunch of nobodies that probably play on 20 Tables at the same time will contantly fold the crap out of you. So you are doomed to collect one blind after another until one of them gets a lucky hand but blows it with the obvious tell of betting after 50 rounds of folding.Long Story short: IT SUCKS!But here comes the solution: POKER NIGHT 2Here you play with an awesome bunch of very indiviual characters that, even though they are played by the AI, are better than most online poker ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. They bluff, they taunt you, they play dirty and when they are drunk they tell once in a while.You love them for the humor and hate them when their Kicker make you lose a fortune. If you liked Poker Night 1 you wil LOVE Poker Night 2.If Poker Night 1 was too easy and repetetive: Give Poker Night 2 a chance! It has WAY more Audio Recordings, the AI is WAY better and you get to do a lot of other stuff while playing Poker. Buy these guys some drinks and make them drunk. Try make them bet their Throphies. Buy new Decks, Felts and Chips.And be honest with me: GladOS as the dealer? ♥♥♥♥ YEAH!

Posted: January 2, 2014
												I tried Poker Night 1 and 2, and 1 is the more-fun game. The personalities in 2 are a little annoying, and the gameplay isn't balanced among the players (Ash won the first 8 pots I played, usually bluffing, but he had the nuts every time he was called down).  This might just be because I'm more familiar with the characters in Poker Night 1, but I didn't have as much fun with the characters in 2.  Claptrap was annoying, and GLaDOS actually became somewhat annoying quickly just by playing off of Claptrap.  Another weird fault was clicking the + and - buttons in the raise screen was not smooth: I would have to click maybe twice per click that is actually registered.  Clicking up a few hundred dollars feels like button mashing until I get there, while in 1, I just click a few times.  I recommend sticking to Poker Night 1.

												this game cheats so badly... especially in omaha game mode... i had a straight... and i was beaten by two pair... then in the next game i had two pair and was beaten by a straight... the rules make no sense in this game... it cant even follow the real rules of hold em poker... i have played this game often enough to know that this computer doesnt follow the generic rules for texas holdem. i'm an avid lover of the game and was hoping for "fair play" when it came to this game... but as usual i was disappointed to find that this game cheats, some card combinations for the "players hand" are completely ignored, you could have a full royal straight and you are beaten by 2 pairs of aces and 2's, you could have 2 pairs of aces and kings in the next hand and then be beaten by a flush of  A, 2, 3, 4, 5... i love this game when it follows the rules and doesnt stack the deck in the computer's favor... i have played this game often enough to see that... as well as have an at least basic understanding of video games to see it as well. this game will frustrate you over things like this... either glitches or purposefully designed... it needs to be spread as others have noticed things like this as well

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game.FIrstly I think TellTale games are amazing. I was super excited when I heard about this one.The first few hours are enjoyable and fun provided you know whom the characters are and get the references.After maybe 3 hours of gaming you will find the dialogue tedious and repetitive.The games feel rigged (of course maybe I just have horrible luck) and after a while I figure out you can just bluff big and always win the majority of the time. Throwing all in seems to win 70% of the time.But at times when you know you've got an amazing hand, three other players somehow also have super amazing hands.Check out my screen shots but one time three players had Straight Flushes... what the?!!!Biggest disappointment is Bruce Campbel DOES NOT voice Ash from Army of Darkness... what gives?!!That alone would have made this game worth while but sadly disappointing.After a while getting insulted constantly by the characters really wears you down and you will find yourself disliking them in their respective games/movies/genres... Sad that this could have had amazing potential but Tell Tale Games got lazy with this one. A real shame.Graphics: Nice and decent.Sound/Music: Decent enough but repetitive voice acting and lack of Bruce Campbell makes it lackingGame-play: There are better Hold 'em games out there sadly.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												This is something that is so worth it, especially for the small price, that I look at this review and think to myself:  "This is such an obvious deal, what else needs to be said?"  I'll put it this way, whether you like Poker or you don't like it, it's amazing to see a cast of such popular characters co-existing in one game like this. This game is just fun, pure and simple. Win or lose, you'll enjoy it. If you don't know anything about poker, this is how you should learn .. no matter what happens, if you have a good sense of humor, you'll love the commentary from the characters as they make idle conversation, mock each other and poke fun at their own backgrounds while you guys play a "friendly" game of Poker. If you unlock an entire set of bonus things, like the cards, table and chips associated with one of their themes, their conversations will sometimes steer more into that particular theme. Like, if you unlock all the PORTAL stuff, and the Inventory becomes a science lab, GLADOS will make a disturbing offer to the rest of the cast. I've heard pretty much all their dialogue from playing this game as much as I have and I still find it hilarious. This is the game I play while I'm eating, or that final thing before I go to bed, or any time where I just wanna have fun without having to put any real effort into it (aside from thinking). Buy it, you'll love it if you love these characters and their worlds.

Then everyones favourite dancing robot flirt with the emotionless death machine that is GLaDOS. I was so happy at that moment I didn't care that Brock Samson got a flush on the river card. This is a pure pleasure even if you don't care about poker, and just enjoy video games (or the movie/tv-series) and their characters. 8.1/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												I`ve always wanted a good single player poker game that actually played realistically with decent characters. This game does that.It starts you off in a dark  underground pub or bar and introduces you to 4 characters, only two of which I recognised which was Ash, and not from the crappy tv series either.  I also recognised Max, while never having played the game, know by reputation. Or is he called sam? I get mixed up between the dog and bunny. However, the characters reveal their personalities as you play the game. It`s more slow a reveal than the first game, but nicely paced in my view.The characterisations and how they play is really the best part of the game. Some of the jokes and stories are great.You can buy drinks for your opponents to weaken their skills, a bit silly really and they never refuse. I would`ve preferred it without. Sexy bar lady though with an air of `can`t be be bothered` to her.You also have a  female voiced robot that deals the cards. i prefrred when the cards where just dealth naturally in the 1st game. She can be also highly annoying both in attitude and voice. I preferred the original way without the dumb dealer robot.Game feels a little easier to win. Maybe too easy. You can free extra tables and card design but there`s not much to free up.My main wish would be for more choice in characters with just as much depth to play against. Make it about 10 with clothing variety so each game feels fresh. Yes, it would be a fair amount of work, but I`d pay £30 for it.Anyway recommended.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												All the fun of Poker Night 1 but even more to offer.  An all new cast of cult classic characters will have you laughing hard at their discussions and bickering.  The poker is just as good as ever and you can read more in my Poker Night 1 review to see what I mean and this time they even added an Omaha style just to mix it up a bit.  The addition of the odds screen is a fun little aspect and something I wished was in the first one.  Again their are lots of unlockables but with the bonus that if everything is deployed for a single character the entire Inventory changes and they get a new outfit.  Speaking of, more bounty unlockables for extra content in Team Fortress 2 , Borderlands 2, etc.  The dialogue was one of the best and worst things about Poker Night 1 in that the first time you hear something funny about or from a character you especially like it's hillarious.  At least until the 6th time you've heard it.  There are much much more conversations between characters so the repitition is way less but unavoidably there is some.  The only real problem is coincidently the infamous host of this game: GlaDos.  She was the big reason everyone was talking about this game but she's actually the worst part of it because all of her dialogue is criticism of you.  You bet and she scolds you, you fold and she scolds you, you go all-in and she scolds you, you call a bet and she scolds you, you win the game and the scolds you (no, not joking).  And her lines are much fewer and are by far the most annoying and repetitive you will hear.  I've gotten a reflex when I see her come down from the cieling I mute my sound and when she leaves I unmute it and it's way better.Anyway, point is that I enjoy card games like Spades, Solitaire, and Hearts that come with computers and this is that times 100 with Moxxi's cleavage on top of it.  I play it every week.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game.FIrstly I think TellTale games are amazing. I was super excited when I heard about this one.The first few hours are enjoyable and fun provided you know whom the characters are and get the references.After maybe 3 hours of gaming you will find the dialogue tedious and repetitive.The games feel rigged (of course maybe I just have horrible luck) and after a while I figure out you can just bluff big and always win the majority of the time. Throwing all in seems to win 70% of the time.But at times when you know you've got an amazing hand, three other players somehow also have super amazing hands.Check out my screen shots but one time three players had Straight Flushes... what the?!!!Biggest disappointment is Bruce Campbel DOES NOT voice Ash from Army of Darkness... what gives?!!That alone would have made this game worth while but sadly disappointing.After a while getting insulted constantly by the characters really wears you down and you will find yourself disliking them in their respective games/movies/genres... Sad that this could have had amazing potential but Tell Tale Games got lazy with this one. A real shame.Graphics: Nice and decent.Sound/Music: Decent enough but repetitive voice acting and lack of Bruce Campbell makes it lackingGame-play: There are better Hold 'em games out there sadly.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												This is something that is so worth it, especially for the small price, that I look at this review and think to myself:  "This is such an obvious deal, what else needs to be said?"  I'll put it this way, whether you like Poker or you don't like it, it's amazing to see a cast of such popular characters co-existing in one game like this. This game is just fun, pure and simple. Win or lose, you'll enjoy it. If you don't know anything about poker, this is how you should learn .. no matter what happens, if you have a good sense of humor, you'll love the commentary from the characters as they make idle conversation, mock each other and poke fun at their own backgrounds while you guys play a "friendly" game of Poker. If you unlock an entire set of bonus things, like the cards, table and chips associated with one of their themes, their conversations will sometimes steer more into that particular theme. Like, if you unlock all the PORTAL stuff, and the Inventory becomes a science lab, GLADOS will make a disturbing offer to the rest of the cast. I've heard pretty much all their dialogue from playing this game as much as I have and I still find it hilarious. This is the game I play while I'm eating, or that final thing before I go to bed, or any time where I just wanna have fun without having to put any real effort into it (aside from thinking). Buy it, you'll love it if you love these characters and their worlds.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												I don't watch Venture Bros, I've never played Sam and Max, or Evil Dead, and I didn't like Borderlands 2. So basically I just bought it for the poker. The game at first seemed charming but after 45 minutes of play it got stale, the line that were funny, or clever fell flat after I heared them multiple times. I continued playing just for the hell of it, but the game didn't seem to become any better. In fact, the more I played the worse my luck seemed to get, and the more annoyed I got with the game. I lost multiple all-in hands when I had more than a 90% chance to win, so maybe the game is rigged or maybe just the cosmos hate me.Overall Poker Night 2 is a fairly meh game with stale repeated dialog, and decent (possibly rigged) poker. That's all it's got going for it, dialog and poker, and neither of them are even that good. If you like poker go ahead and buy it, but buy it when it's on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												It's a poker game, it's only gameplay mechanic is playing poker. So if you don't like poker then don't play the game, it is as simple as that. The game is quite humorous because of its characters that branch from different game franchises, GLADOS from Portal, Claptrap from Borderlands and others. However the brilliant writing is ruined by the repetitiveness of them, the same jokes are constantly repeated and it got to the point where I just muted the game because I couldn't stand the repeated lines anymore. The unlocks help to customize your experience and help to keep you playing. The game suffers from only having two modes, it would be much better if the game was able to blend in some more modes. 7/10- Poker is fun, characters are fun, jokes are fun but are repeated and the game needs more modes.

The cards are randomly generated for the AI and will adapt depending what the player has as each hand is played (kinda hard to explain). Also the emulated card system itself is well below par of, say alot of the big online poker games. But I guess that isn't what the game is about. Even so, the game just becomes infuriating with the daft curveballs and the faults.So really unless you just want to watch alot of dialog and unusual characters gathering togather I cannot recommend this game at all. The previous game had slightly better mechanics too (if slightly less interesting characters).

												Essentially this is a PC, Single-player poker game. But it's a very, very good one. If you think you're pretty good at poker, then this can still be a good challenge for you (provided you dont read up on the steam guides to see what everyones tells are!); and if you don't know then this game can teach you pretty well.The art style is an amalgamation of the various games the characters come from but the seamless interactions between them means that you really dont notice the fact that some are cellshaded and others like GLADOS are realistic.The humour is pretty good although theres only so many times you can hear 'Great day in the morning!' and not be annoyed by it.All in all if you want a game to kick back and relax with then this is definitely a game for you!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 18, 2013
												Pros:-The characters. All of the opponents in Poker Night 2 are interesting. The banter between all of them is interesting (at least on the first go) and I seem to have learned something about Sam & Max, Borderlands, and The Evil Dead series from these exchanges.  However, poker Brock does seem kind of flat compared to TV Brock. Something that was obvious to me,  since I started watching the show about the same time I bought this game.-The items. They stuff you get for TF2 is the only things that really motivated me to get this game. I really want the Long Fall Boots. -The backgrounds are cool. I personally enjoyed the Venture Brothers set. Cons:-The game cheats. I could not believe how many times I’ve had a decent hand (three of a kind, straights, flushes, and at the very least really strong two pairs) and then been blown out of the water. One time during the final showdown of a tournament I had a full house (three Kings and two Aces) and I lost to a four of a kind (four Aces, yhaa for serious). Never have I been more frustrated by a game of chance in my entire life. And forget about attempting to win by bluffing or with a single pair. I’ve only down that once and a handful of times respectively. -The banter gets old/takes too long/is insulting. While the opponents will engage in story telling with each other, there isn’t a moment when the player isn’t constantly bad mouthed. It’s especially bad when you’re on a losing streaking even though you’re getting good hands. Not only that but it’s the same stories and banter that you’ve already heard a hundred times in the last few minutes. I’d be fine with that if you could skip it, but a lot of the banter locks you out from taking your turn. Overall:There really isn’t anything that needs to be said about this game. Essentially it turns your computer into a glorified video poker machine. The only real impetus that has even kept me playing was so that I could score some swag for Team Fortress 2.The game isn’t bad, but I just wish that the game’s cheap tactics didn’t kill any of the fun that I had had with it. 4/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 14, 2013
												Prior to this game, I was under the impression that a series was supposed to get better as it went on. Apparently Telltale is losing their touch...Poker Night was a tough act to follow, and while this game had the potential to top it with its cast of characters, it fails hard on many levels, not the least of which is the CPU's blatant cheating (why on earth would they make a cheating AI when they had a perfectly-working non-cheating one in the first game? Cheating AIs are only supposed to be employed when there is no better alternative ... or when your game is Mario Kart). Went all-in after being dealt a pair of aces? Someone else got a pair of jacks, and the next card on the table is 100% going to be a jack. Game tells you you have a 99% chance of winning? Your opponent is guaranteed to get the one card that would let them win. Just folded? Oh look - THERE'S that card you needed! Too bad you'll never see it again.There is also a disproportionately large percentage of the dialog dedicated solely to insulting the player. I know it's supposed to be funny, but when your game isn't exactly relying on its own fun merit to begin with (face it, the only worthwhile takeaway is the TF2 and BL2 loot), calling the player a moron for playing it is the last thing you want to do if you expect them to keep playing.Speaking of dialog, what banter isn't used to call the player an idiot is repetitive and dull. The characters have different conversations based on the unlockable theme currently in use, but there are only maybe 4 or 5 per theme, meaning you'll hear the same crap over and over unless you change tables every tournament. They're not nearly as funny as the first game either. There are some humorous animations when others get busted out (if you aren't the first one to bust out, which you will be 90% of the time - again, cheating CPUs), but they don't always play, so you'll likely never see most of them. (Speaking of animations, characters, especially GLaDOS, get frozen mid-animation A LOT. It's these kinds of bugs that remind you why testing is necessary.)NOT recommended. Save your $5 and find something worthwhile, like Just Cause 2 when it goes on sale again, which it does often.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 29, 2013
												Let's face it: Texas Hold'em is the most manly gambling game right after Russian Roulette. You have to stay focused througout the whole tournament and you have to play it cool even if the River Card is completing your Full House.The problen is: In your every day life you will not get a lot of chances to sit down at a round table in a smoke filled backroom of your local pub and play this awesome game with 4 other soldiers of fortune.So you will most likely restort to online poker. A faceless bunch of nobodies that probably play on 20 Tables at the same time will contantly fold the crap out of you. So you are doomed to collect one blind after another until one of them gets a lucky hand but blows it with the obvious tell of betting after 50 rounds of folding.Long Story short: IT SUCKS!But here comes the solution: POKER NIGHT 2Here you play with an awesome bunch of very indiviual characters that, even though they are played by the AI, are better than most online poker ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. They bluff, they taunt you, they play dirty and when they are drunk they tell once in a while.You love them for the humor and hate them when their Kicker make you lose a fortune. If you liked Poker Night 1 you wil LOVE Poker Night 2.If Poker Night 1 was too easy and repetetive: Give Poker Night 2 a chance! It has WAY more Audio Recordings, the AI is WAY better and you get to do a lot of other stuff while playing Poker. Buy these guys some drinks and make them drunk. Try make them bet their Throphies. Buy new Decks, Felts and Chips.And be honest with me: GladOS as the dealer? ♥♥♥♥ YEAH!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 27, 2013
												Okay, first, if you're buying this for the items, then you have to still not suck at poker, or else you'll never win them, as opposed to Poker Night's save scumming until you can get the other guy all in.That said, you no longer need to knock the owner out, just win the game, and a reward will stay on the table until you win it.So..  the game itself.Like Poker Night, the cast are pretty great. Especially since Sam has brought Max into the inventory once again, so he often interjects, mimics and/or brandishes his gun to humourous effect now that he's not tied to the table. Ash and Brock are fairly non-energetic conversationalists, but you need someone to balance the Claptrap/Sam+Max hilarity, and Glados just demeans everyone.The tournament organiser also interjects more often, lending an offended upper class voice to the conversation.Getting the players drunk would likely affect the conversation as well.In all, I think the conversations in this game are more humourous and varied than the first.As for the Poker, Omaha seems like a much more interesting game than Texas, purely because your hole cards afford more viability in potential flops. So your hand is far less likely to be crap or excellent until that river goes down. As a result you see more rivers and can then bet intelligently off that information.Some things could be improved, such as not looking over every characters shoulder when watching the remainder of the match. Just put the values down beneath their name or split the screen, otherwise it takes too much time.But the poker's better, the characters and conversation better (all though get back to me after I've memorised all the lines), and the prize distribution less frustrating to those who can play. This is probably the best poker game I've played.
